u.u: My name is Kris Manjapra and I am an Assistant Professor here at the Tufts University in the History Department and it’s my great pleasure and honour to be the chairperson for this semester series for our lecture series at the Centre for South Asian Indian Ocean studies at Tufts. This year beginning last fall as Professor Ayesha Jalal who is the Director of the centre was still in residence with us we began a series called Islam on the Indian Ocean rim and this semester continues that theme we have had a number of illustrious speakers and semesters and in fact we are on the up and up as this afternoon or this evening we have with us tremendously articulate imaginative and influential thinker public intellectual journalists and really one might also say that an academic given how academically informed his scholarship is and also how well read he is within academia and respected and of course,I am speaking of Robert Kaplan.

We have a special event because in some ways it is a special feature because Robert Kaplan is here with us along with Professor Saugata Bose who I would also like to thank very much for his contributions to the discussions that’s going to happen.I just want to just very briefly introduce both Robert Kaplan and then Saugata Bose and give a brief kind of blue print of how the discussion will work because we are hoping to have a conversation that will also involve the audience and then turn it over to our guests. So, Robert Kaplan is a national correspondent for the Atlantic and senior fellow at the centre for a new American security in Washington D.C. and it’s really his long and illustrious career including at least 12 books many of them have been on the list best selling list over the last sort of 3 decades in fact but it’s really his latest book in fact Monsoon the Indian Ocean and the future of America power published in 2010 that this discussion will revolve around.

You know when I think of Robert Kaplan’s work, I think perhaps even of Iban Batuta or I think of Alexander Von Humboldt or I think of Thessegar some of the great travelling intellectuals of not only our times but also of earlier times and the kind of ability to provide a synoptic overview as well as great detail about some of the most important changes that are geo politically taking place in our world today so that is the theme kind of gathers us here.Saugata Bose, Professor Bose is the gardener professor Of Oceanic History at Harvard University and he also is serving at a special capacity over this year and in coming years as the Chairperson for the mentor group at the Presidency University in Calcutta an important role that involved restructuring education in Bengal.

Professor Bose is the author of many, many influential books path breaking books for our field and beyond the field as South Asian studies and most recently his majesty’s opponent Subhas Chandra Bose and India’s struggle against Empire which came out with Harvard University Press in 2011 so as not to extend you know my voice too far in the evening’s proceedings let me cut short and let me say that it’s really an honour to have two global thinkers who know the Indian Ocean world so well who can speak about what Robert Kaplan so eloquently calls the Rim land of the Indian Ocean and it’s import for world politics with us today. In terms of how we will proceed we asked Robert whether he might first provide a 20 perhaps 30 minute introduction to his work to some of the themes of his book and then there would be a kind of free flowing conversation between Robert and Saugata and following that we will open it up to the audience for further discussion so having said all of that may I hand it over to you.

well thank you it’s really a great privilege and honour to be here Saugata’s book a Hundred horizons helped and inspired me to write my own book so it’s you know though it’s kind of a double feature for me too and I have his book on hard copy by the way and let me start this way you know in Washington everyone wants to reduce things the policy terms and people kept asking me at the Presidency and the national security Affairs what’s your strategy going to be for the Indian Ocean and my response was that we don’t have a strategy, it’s a concept it’s not a strategy and it’s a concept because it helps you to unite the world, the world the greater middle east and the world on the Western Pacific because we think that we are too much prisoners of cold war in various studies where we separate out the globe or Asia particularly into artificial divisions of the middle Central Asia, South Asia, South east Asia, East Asia and so forth.

And what the Indian ocean as a concept allows you to do is think organically in terms of the fluid organic continual whereby the middle east does all this trade with China for instance and in our day all the energy the oil and the natural gas is in the greater middle east in the Arabian Peninsula and the Arabian plato and the customers are increasingly in the middle class of coastal China, south Korea, Japan and so and the Indian Ocean is the great connector, it’s the inter State it’s the global high way interstate in this maritime world where despite jet and information age 90% of all commercial goods that travel inter continentally do so by sea.

You know this symbol of the global aid is actually the super taker either an oil super taker or one of those big ships with like a thousand containers on that you see so the Indian Ocean I said to Washington policy makers allows you to think more creatively allows you to think of your Asia as just one united Rim land you know the navigable Southern rim land and because the Northern rim land of your Asia is all I spot you know in North of Russia.

So we have been prisoners of cold war studies, Americans have been the prisoners of 8.00 projection which puts North and South America in the Centre and splits up the pacific and Indian Ocean and the edges and therefore the edges of consciousness and what the Indian Ocean allows us to do is to see the world whole and to see really it’s centre over the next few decades because by 2050 there’s going to be about 9 Billion people in the world and 7 of those 9 Billion are going to be living vaguely around on the Indian Ocean Rim Land the greater Indian Ocean Rim Land taken if you put together the populations of east Asia, South East Asia, South Asia, the middle east what you have got there is almost 7 of 9 Billion people of the world

so the Indian Ocean is the unifier it’s the centre of the map for the 21st century in that sense the centre of conflict and a centre also of trade and cultural relations and my theme you know to me it’s what the most unique and relevant thing for our century about the Indian Ocean is the monsoon because the monsoon winds more than any other wind path over nor predictable you know blowing North east, south, west then reversing themselves by a 180 degrees south, west and north east and of course with a lot of small variations inside the Bay of Bengal and others but nevertheless because of the predictability of this wind system it allows sailors to calculate sailing times in advance and thus the Indian Ocean did not have to the age of steam ships you know we see united back in the 18th medieval era remember when Vasco-da-gama sailed from what is today’s Kenya to what is today’s south west India, half the distance of the Indian Ocean thousands of miles he did it in 23 days which is an amazing feat if any of you or your parents are recreational sailors you should know this.

and he was able to do this not because he discovered the wind system or the Portuguese didn’t discover it was the medieval era who re acquainted them with it. Re acquainted them with it because the Romans and the Greeks may have known about it you know to a large extent you know if you hunt down the estuary in Bengal you may find some Roman coins you know or some Greek coins because the Romans and the Greeks got that far and so because of the monsoon winds because it did not have to wait for the age of the steam ships to unite it you know you have the remains of the 8th century mosques in China you have large Malay communities from the East Indies in Madagasca just off the coast of East Africa.

You have Almanis all along the coast of East Africa, you have Gujarati’s from North West India all over the Indian Ocean map, You have Yemeni’s in Indonesia you know significant populations everywhere with, everyone with everywhere because in the cultural sense because of the wind system it was a united community and so there was like a unifying element in the medieval era that policy makers today would do well to study because it is quite relevant how well they can conceive of a whole Eurasian trade and security system.

Another thing that the Indian Ocean does is it allows you to think of Islam not as a dessert religion but spread relatively, quickly by the sword across the sands of North Africa but spread very gradually over the course of the centuries by sophisticated merchants in ships, I just got back from Malaysia for instance I spend a month in Malaysia and Singapore and its fascinating you know Malaysia may be one of the most influential countries in the Muslim world in terms of where Islam is going because Malaysians a democracy been so for quite a few decades not a perfect one by any means we can study that and it’s also one of the most technologically developed countries in the world so it’s become a high tech functioning democracy where 60% of the country are Muslims and interact with 20% ethnic Chinese and another 9% who are Indians and this is all the residue of the monsoon wind system merchants of gradual conversions over the course of centuries and we can talk similarly about Indonesia and other places

and as I said we are going back to a classical super region. It’s possible that in the course of the next few decades we will see canals and land bridge projects connecting the Bay of Bengal with South China Sea being as energy prices go up if you can consider that global energy demand is going to go up by almost 50% over the next 20 – 30 years half of that’s going to come from India and China even with Chinese growth slowing down you are entering a world with where there are going to be more consumers more middle class consumers for energy and goods and that is going to mean a sea a straight of Malaika a straight of sudamacassa and Lomba and one more crowded with ships

and you are going to need other so the Malaysians are exploring land bridge projects across the Peninsular Malaysia there’s renewed talk about a proper canal across the so that the Indian Ocean proper and the South China Sea are going to be liable and much more organic in terms of their relations with each other in the course of the coming decades and the South China Sea let me tell you is there we have got more than half of the world merchant fleet tiny age a third of all maritime traffic world wide the oil transport through the Malaika straight from the Indian Ocean with the South China Sea is triple the amount that passes Sewers canal and fifteen times the amount that pass the Panama canal so we are really talking about you know the nerve centre you know the real coagulated nerve centre of the world, of Eurasia going forward and the real drama here this strategic drama is that the West is gradually ever so gradually receding and indigenous powers arrive.

Globalization is about navies and air Force’s much more than about marine and army corps because navy’s and air force you know help protect sea lines communication. They project power and they often have peace keeping functions that armies and Marine Corps you know there’s an old saying that armies convey navies make port visits and it’s really true in a way. The American navies platoing size make it even smaller, it’s gone down from almost 600 ships in 1980’s to less than 300 hundred ships war ships today. It’s unclear if they sustain themselves as these numbers going forward over the next 20 or 30 years meanwhile India and China are growing dramatically bigger navies. You know china will have more sub marines afloat than United States navy in about 15 years and China is not just developing these quite diesel electric sub marines but nuclear sub marines which means that China has blue water oceanic ambitions because you only build or develop nuclear sub marines if you want to operate in the great Ocean’s.

Because what nuclear power does it means that you don’t have to refuel. You are only limited by the amount of food to can carry which is about 90 days on a sub marine so China is developing a great navy and air force much as the united States did at the turn of the 20th century when United States became a great power for the first time and the United States suddenly had trading interests all over the world and dug the Panama Canal and built a great navy in order to protect those interests and China seems to be following very much American pattern in that regard. There’s a lot of details I can go into about everything that China’s doing with it you know cyber warfare capabilities its fourth and fifth generations fighter jets you know it’s in large fleets of vessels but they are very serious about ultimately protecting their own sea lines of communication not being dependent on the American navy for this.

India’s navy over the last few decades going forward is also increasing by leaps and bounds and it’s not just them the increase in defence spending Vietnam, Malaysia, Singapore is astounding, it’s all I mean it’s the submarines or the new blinks everybody wants more you know some countries are not sure about what to do with them but they are buying and they are training groups. Japan and South Korea continue to modernize their fleets so there’s a trend here which is indigenous powers taking control of the region gradually in a very military sense and while the American navy and Air force will continue to dominate it’s going to be a far more subtle deeper situation you know if the present trend continues and the only thing that can stop present trends frankly is if China were to undergo such a profound socio economic political crisis that would impinge upon their developments projects and that is not likely.

China will have a profound socio economic crisis but probably not deep enough and in a direction that would in the rising defence budgets and so this is the post direct Afghanistan world going forward and if it’s a peaceful world bee taken centrally also whish brings pipelines going from Central Asia into the Indian Ocean region. You know china is the sort of moving vertically South along the Indian Ocean you know financing port projects in Pakistan, Sri Lanka, and Burma and lately in Kenya and lamo in Kenya instead of Sri Lanka, all of these port projects tell a different story the one in Gawadar in Pakistan is a great beautiful port that I have seen but it’s a kind of road to nowhere at the moment because of security concerns that the Chinese are going forward the one in Burma is not a road to nowhere that is taking its national gas from the Bay of Bengal and transporting in roads and pipelines across central and northern Burma in the southern China and province within a number of years.

The port in Sri Lanka that they are building is quite impressive and you know and comes in at a time when Chinese influences Sri Lanka is greater never before because of the help China gave Sri Lanka Sri Lankan regime in winning the civil war, China has hopes to transport world from across southern Sudan and Kenya and that again might be for the sky project given the instability between and the fighting between Sudan proper and South Sudan. I was in Beijing for 2 weeks in December meeting with people about this and you know Chinese would say to me well it’s just that our companies who are doing this, we just have a peaceful commercial purpose along the Indian Ocean and my response was that’s what the Americans said a thousand years ago.

People don’t sit around the table and say now we are going to start an Empire, Empire’s happen in your sleep so to speak you know they begin as commercial ventures or for specific legitimate purposes and then they grow and expand if they did itself question continues to become dynamic and to the world and so it begins its commercial ventures like an expedition against piracy along Venuses northern Adriatic on the Adriatic coast of the former Yugoslavia in a thousand AD Venice started to establish a commercial colonies. You know 200 years later Venice you know controls the whole of eastern mediterainean so we will see where these port projects go within the next few decades you know where will be China remember the British east India Company the Dutch east India Company began it’s purely commercial venture and evolved into much grandeur details in that sense.

India is also expanding horizontally along the Indian Ocean developing you know India will not go along with the US in terms of embargoing around they are going to continue to do business with Iran because they need the natural gas that around too so India is also building pipeline in Burma you know this way to transport the natural gas in the Bay of Bengal through Bangladesh to West Bengal and India and around Bangladesh and again I think one of the exiting developments as I finish my book is the opening up of Burma.The opening up of Burma if it progresses and that is a big if because Burma is not a question of snapping your finger holding an election it’s really about ethnic reconciliation and you know ending a low level you know fighting between the Burman and the army and the various ethnic irregular forces around the horseshoe of the valley but if Burma can truly open up that could liberate the North East India the chicken bone of India which is being cut off by geographical isolation and a hilly and somewhat mountainous demography in parts.

And so then it’s small resurgence underdevelopment but with the developed with an opening of Burma and 25.08 and other areas the North east India could finally be liberated you know Burma rather than a place for India and China competing fight over for commercial advantage could become a pulsing centre of trade in itself. There’s a good book written about that just came out recently in India and Burma meet and which said just a travel book but it go there’s quite some depth so if you think of Burma opening up and you think 20 years ahead with a stable Afghanistan hopefully a stable Pakistan you have a world of routes and pipelines connecting inner and southern Eurasia to the sea in many different directions where you have recreation of the tang Empire for the 9th century from China doing more and more trade with Iran through central Asia you know how people have this silly argument is it is Eurasia’s development is going to be by land by sea it’s going to be both.You know it’s very much going to be both.

and so I think that this is really going to be a developing, pulsing area that is not going to be easily divided into cold war area studies and war because the inter connections between the various parts of the Indian Ocean Rim the greater Indian Ocean Rim Land from the Middle East to the Western Pacific are going to continue to develop and be vast and I will stop here and thank you.

so that we can have a conversation, I don’t intend to offer a long commentary but I think we’ll let us just see it as a conversation. First of all Thank you for providing such a wonderful summary of the few of the issues that you had raised in your book and you know I really admire your book not just for the writing but here is one strategic analyst who had actually read all the scholarly literature on the Indian Ocean which is very rare you know and which is why you know there’s such a depth of analysis in Monsoon.

Let me begin by raising sort of a large questions about the relations between Oceans and Continents I do that because you know this particular project Islam on the Indian Ocean rim is I think is very imaginatively conceived, at one level it takes the vast Indian Ocean as it’s campus and explores all of the connections across this Ocean, economic, cultural, political but then the project seeks to two river valley’s or deltas, the Indus valley on either side of the border that’s the great India and Pakistan and the Ganges delta on either sides of the borders of Bangladesh and India. So I would like to start by looking at the sort of the big picture the vast canvas first and then perhaps look at these particular river valley’s and deltas which are connected to the larger Indian Ocean world.

My own sense is that and here is something that you suggested to at the end of your remarks that continents and Oceans you know Asia and the Indian Ocean are conceptually not in an adversarial relationship. I think it is important to underscore how old oceanic connections have been and how important they continue to be as you emphasize 90% of the commodities still travel by ships. On the other hand there always have been very deep of course this is a concept of that 30.02 who has written this book “The Mediterranean” showing how in fact there were narrow land which connected the Mediterranean world with Russia, Poland, Germany, France and so on

And so in the case of the Indian Ocean and Asia as well I think there are these land connections in inter regional arenas can be connected by Oceanic flows on the other hand there could be some other important land routes often going from the ports deep into the interior of the continents and this was in some ways brought home to me in a recent trip to China in October I travelled from Kolkata by air to Kurning which is the capital of Unan province in Southern China and it’s actually such a short distance it was a 2 hour flight and people are beginning to talk about K2K, Kolkata to Kurning connection. From Kurning, I took another flight another 2 hours to Shiyan the capital of Tan dynasty china and there of course I saw one of the mosques that you were eluding to the great Shiyan mosque going back to the 740’s.

Mosque constructed in a Chinese architectural style but with Arabic calligraphy and clearly here was a city Shiyan which was at the eastern end of trade routes that connected the Arab world, the Persian world, the Indian world with China now these clearly had been land connections. Shiyan is so far from both the Indian Ocean and the Pacific but also in addition to the Presidency University which Kris mentioned I am involved in an effort to re-establish an Asian International University at Nalanda which was the oldest University in the world and flourished from the 5th to the 12th centuries but if you look at the scholar pilgrims who came in from China, Korea, Japan, South east Asia the most famous ones sometimes came by Sea, Eijing came you know via Sumatra and learnt Sanskrit there and then arrived and then went back by land you know other famous pilgrims came by land went back by sea and then Shyian of course in addition to the great Shiyan mosque I saw the old goose or rather the big goose Bagoda which is associated with Xuan-Xan who had been in Nalanda in the 7th century as a teacher.

So I was just wondering as you pointed out you know the Indian Ocean is a concept you know that’s what one has to recognize one can’t devise strategy in relation to separate bits of that world in old areas that studies small but given what’s going to be happening in Afghanistan and Central Asia how do you see the links between the Indian Ocean world and you know the continental interiors of Asia playing out?

First of all thanks for that lovely compliment and when you said about the Gangetic plane and the Indian Ocean I thought of Amitabh Ghosh’s recent novel at the opium trade you know look at the geography of the opium trade which takes you from the central Ganges down to the Bay of Bengal by ship up in to China and the opium trade was just another trade route essentially the same way in fact drugs come from Mexico all along age old trade routes in to the united States the same trade route that kerning now use that is in his expeditions of discovery in the 16th century so i think it’s fascinating to think in terms of like the Gangetic plane coming down to the Bay Of Bengal and the Indus river valley coming down close to the Arabian sea and you know people there’s this cliché that Pakistan is artificial in the sense that no it’s not.

It’s in Indus valley nation which is you know a very much set up in the ink block of demography which had been in the centre of previous Empires whether it is Ghaznavid or rather going back in to History you know the whole area of all Hind that Andre wink writes about in his book so you have from the Indian Ocean emanating outwork you have the Ganges river valley you have the Indus river valley you have the erewadi river valley and these are path ways in to the interiors that in turn at the head of those path ways connect into central Asia because take Punjab for instance you know Punjab is in the heart of Indus valley civilization in the northern heart.

It’s the closest real demographic hub to southern central Asia so it reach’s up into Northern Afghanistan and the southern former southern Saudi union and reaches down Indus valley all the way to Karachi and then into the wider world and thee wider sea and it’s increasing and it crosses many what in the historical sense or artificial states in the sense that all states are artificial I mean where do you draw the line borders anywhere and I think the biggest drama over the coming years Chinese growth rate we know is going to come down to about 7% but that’s still 7% that’s still a lot compared to our own. It’s going to be how China reaches’ out in to all these regions through trade and as you said it’s also a 2 hours flight from Kolkata to Kurning you know imagine all the rounds across Burma and through North east India that will make it in about 20 years a comfortable land trip along you know highways

You know let’s talk a little bit more about china you know of course you know reading Amitabh Ghosh’s novel Sea of Poppies, you know there’s this wonderful image of Sacrey Reed the son of a maryled free women who travels on the ship the IBIs and its only after he reaches the Hooghly river that he meets the owner of this black bata which has been refitted a man called Ben Burnham and Ben Burnham tells Sacrey Reed that this ship is not going to be used on its first voyage to carry opium to China from the Gangetic delta because the Chinese are still having problems having the benefits of free trade but then it will be a different kind of a cargo and of course sacrey Reed is quite concerned that you mean you know you are going to use it to carry slaves haven’t your laws actually abolished that trade and of course Ben Burgham relies yes the laws sort of have done so but there is going to be this coolie trade because you know when the doors of freedom are close to one people then Africans it’s gets open to the Asiatic and so then

and so you know there was an Indian Ocean connection even in the 19th century which transformed the older tie across the Indian Ocean because this was a connection of opium between India and China of Indian labourers from India from that same sort of Gangeteic heartland of Bihar and UP to support Mauritius and the Indian heart of the Indian Ocean world but you know coming back to China I think you are absolutely right that what has been new in the contemporary phase of globalization is China’s decision after a hiatus of several hundred years since the times of Jan hay to project it’s power economic as well as naval military in the Indian Ocean

so is it your sense that it is the writing and publication of ‘Monsoon’ the Chinese leadership has become rather more aggressive and assertive than they have been because there was always a sense of that the Chinese leadership is very pragmatic it did not want to take steps too early that might in fact upset the United States of America but in relation to the South China Sea be certainly but also in terms of its presence in many of the areas that they are building infrastructure in ports and in the Indian Ocean do you see a new assertiveness on the part of China that may not have even existed say 3 to 4 years ago.

It’s not a straight line what had happened after the western financial crisis with China had a fit of arrogance and decided to send more you know more warships into this South China Sea to make planes to actually publish this historic map to dash line or tongue which claims you know most of the South China sea which goes against the lobs of the sea treaty and everything and this caused the reaction you know suddenly the Vietnamese and the Malaysian and others were in America’s line they all ran to America for and the Japanese who just got through Government transitions and were cool to the United nations southern embraced the United States because of this new Chinese aggression but then it seems that the Chinese back off , they seem to back off somewhat considerably keep one thing in mind there’s not nearly as much policy co-ordination in Beijing as even there is in the United States you know the ministries you got 15 different governmental departments in ministries that deal with the South China Sea and there is not even yet from what I can gather from what they call a small leading group of top policy makers who co-ordinate grand strategy on different subjects.

The Chinese have been making bigger in roads to Mauritius into Africa specially this just goes forward regardless of the official policy pursued by Chinese companies and it is the Chinese dig for iron ores in central southern Africa exploit for oil they find themselves getting more and more involved than the domestic politics of these countries which come back to haunt them. This all being said keep in mind that the Chinese leadership first because of the transition its going through now to a new leader but also because of the economic problems is 95% focus domestically, its focussed much greater extent domestically than any American president’s focus domestically so a lot of what we are seeing is the people’s liberation army, navy policy its policies you know of the foreign ministry and others but the top Chinese leadership is what I will give you an example when Husan Tao came to George W. Bush’s ranch 8 years ago Bush said to him what I would worry about and that keeps me up at night is a second attack like 9/11, what keeps you up at night I mean Husan Tao answered he said I have to provide 25 million more Chinese with jobs every year that’s what keeps me up at night and that’s what leadership is all focussed on.

I think that even the Chinese navvy has different opinions I have been reading articles about this different there’s a hard line faction there’s a more moderate faction who thinks that the south China Sea is just is a distraction, push itself or, one thing that I learned is that people and power or the elites in Beijing think of the 9-line that historical line which just drives every other country in the region today to distraction and anger that the leadership in Beijing the elites recognize that the historic line is simply unrealistic that they will have to make a compromise but the problem is that they have no domestic strategy for doing this because the nationalists are all involved in China and well China is not a democracy it has still the party to dissuade public opinion which is very nationalistic.

Well let’s talk about India and the Indian Ocean a bit and also the convergences and the divergences in the United States and you know sort of Indians sort of positions you know when it comes to critical issues in the Indian Ocean realm . At one level it seems that there is broad convergence between India’s and US sort of perceptions you know one that both have agreed to keep the ceiling secure across the Indian Ocean and that is the major energy route of the world today and so on but there are two areas within the Indian Ocean world where India and United States have not seen eye to eye in the last few years and the present and these are of course in terms of in relation to Burma and Iran so lets you know talk about Burma on Myanmar first

India of course constantly tried to explain to the United States that there is a need for engagement with Myanmar rather than sanctions India had to be engaged with Myanmar partly because China was so heavily involved and India could just not withdraw and also there were connections in terms of the insurgencies in the North east and therefore however audios the regime in Myanmar might have been India felt that there was an element of real politic involved that there had to be engagement and it might seem that so far as Myanmar is concerned you know India’s position has been somewhat vindicated that even the sort of military dictator has opened up a Burma somewhar. Earlier as I was driving today than to Boston I heard on the radio that he’s made a statement about how in fact Burma had been so closed has missed out on the opportunities that globalization had presented.

And of course if things work out in Myanmar and there’s another country of course Bangladesh if Burma and Bangladesh are transformed then one could sort of realize that the dream that you evoked there would be a crescent from Singapore to Kolkata connected by 8 lane highways and you know through Burma and Bangladesh and both Burma and Bangladesh are rich in natural gas resources and so on so there would be connections between the Eastern part of India and the southern china through this particular sort of region so you know would you tend to agree that India’s position relating to Myanmar was in fact the right one over the last 10 years or so and this the united States also come in around to the view that things may change in Myanmar

In fact I was in Kolkata with Thanth minto giving a lecture on the basis of his book and he seemed to think that things look positive in terms of the opening up of political democratic processes with Ann Sun Su kyi having agreed to contest by election that on the ethnic front on the ethnic insurgencies even though there is still a very serious problem with the Gachins by and large some of the truces that have been signed holding things are somewhat better than they had been before but the main worry that Thant mint you know suggested would be how well can Burma can actually manage the opening up of the economy to a larger globalized world because there isn’t much of an expertise within Myanmar to oversee that transitions so I just wondered if you would say a few more words about Myanmar.

I think that the Indians were right all along but at the same time Senator James of Virginia who is a South East Asian expert also agreed that the Indians were right and as soon as the Obama administration came in he kept pushing them to open up with Burma and this was before the regimes guarded changing somewhat. There is but nevertheless that India was engaged in Burma heavily in terms of real politics was very convenient for the United States because the United States can stand by half of the world away and stand on its moral principals knowing in the sense that India was balancing against China and therefore didn’t have to worry about it so to speak so there was that element but then after the Obama administration came into office there was an agreement between the Senator Web and the new Assistant secretary for state for East Asia Kurk Campbell that they would try and open with Burma and it worked and you know it seems to have worked

You know it’s very gradual and you know it seems to be going forward the problem in Burma is that the military had been governing since 1962 there are very few people other than the military who know how to govern know how to run office’s bureaucracy’s and others so I don’t think you can have a complete transition to civilian role, you will have to have a queys eyes civilian military condominium for a number of years to keep it stable because there is very little infrastructure there its kind of a semi filled state in many regards and of course so this is a process that’s going to take years and what will facilitate it is ethnic Burman’s like Aung San Su Chi once they are elected to office can reach out to the minority groups you know all around the world and you know at the same time they don’t completely push the military area all together because the military is as audios as it has been is going to be have as a part of the story

and certainly Aung San Su chi’s father Aung san they had quite a generous view of what you know Burman attitude should be to the non Burman minorities and it was a huge tragedy for Burma that he was assassinated in July 1947 six months before Burma came to full independence. Turning a bit to Iran but also placing it within the large Indian Ocean sort of concept how serious are the dissentions between US and Indian Policy makers when it comes to Iran there seems to be deep anxiety in some Washington circles in what India is doing to Iran India of course imports to about 10% of its oil, I would imagine 10 to 12% from Iran.
